texts.en: Oltimau is 30 years old, married to Nasieku, and supports a family of eight. He is a livestock trader in Nkareta area and has been running the business for the past four years. He earns a monthly income from the livestock trade of about KES 35000. He has borrowed a fourth loan of KES 80,000 from KADET after successfully paying off the previous ones. He intends to purchase more livestock for resale. The anticipated profit will be reinvested to boost his business. Oltimau's hope is to extend his business and improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock to sell.

loans.name: Nata

texts.en: Nata is a 20-year-old married woman. She lives in a small village of Dedoplistskaro district with her husband and father-in-law. Her husband works in physical labor and her father-in-law is a watchmen; they both get a small monthly income that is not enough for the family. Nata decided to start her own business. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of $ 500 to open a trading business. Nata will begin trading clothes and will increase the income of her family.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 57 years old. She lives in the town of Telavi with her husband and two grown children. Diana sells groceries of first necessity in a store located in the crowded street of Telavi. Her clients are locals and passersby as well. The business is going well, but the store is newly started and it needs financial support for further development. Her plan now is to continue to work on her business and to make it grow. Diana applied for the credit to MFO Credo. Her request was approved in the framework of Start Up program, which is joint initiative with Kiva, permitting the vulnerable poor to start or re-start businesses. A loan of $900 will help Diana to improve her store and enlarge the quantity of products. She will buy supplies such as sugar, soft-drinks, snacks, etc to better stock her store. With this loan Diana will expand her grocery store and attract more customers. She promises to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to stock her grocery store well.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is married, 30 years old, and lives in Air Port area with her husband and three children. Only two of her children are in school and her children are between the ages of one and 12. Over five years now, she has been selling rice and soup from a cook shop (restaurant) in the local market. She started this business with money given to her by her husband and learned this way of selling from her mother. The problem she faces is the rainy season. She is requesting a loan to purchase more fish, meat, rice, oil, pepper, etc. for her business. Her plans are to build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more fish, meat, rice, oil, pepper, etc. for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en: Zeinab is a 29-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and two young children who are still attending school. She has worked from her house as hairdresser since 2011 and has eight years of experience working in the same occupation. In addition, her husband works in the Lebanese army and they cooperate together to be able to pay the high costs of living. Today, she is requesting a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase hairdressing equipment, a new chair and vaporization machinery. She is very eager to receive those purchases as she only wants to satisfy her customers' demands. In the future, she hopes to open her own beauty salon where she will receive her customers appropriately.

loans.use: to purchase hairdressing equipment, a new chair, and vaporization machinery.

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is not far from Masai land. He has two children.  His primary income sources are milk from dairy, and he has been doing this work for four years. 

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Weeding." He says his biggest challenge is diseases.   Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Nyangera."

Erick was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Low interest rate."  This client was also asked what he learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session:  "Better services."

His highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked how this loan will benefit him, Erick replied it will provide "milk and manure."   He plans to buy another cow.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Erick owns the following: a cow but not a pig; poultry; a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, and an automobile.   Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in his household mosquito netting, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV, or DVD.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Deo

texts.en: Deo used the previous loan to buy timber to make furniture. He is a 40-year-old, married man, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a carpenter who is gifted in making furniture of all designs, thus attracting a lot of customers. Like all business, he has faced hardships of inadequate capital to meet the demand and price fluctuations, while his dream is to own a showroom in the city center. Deo intends to use the loan to buy timber to make more furniture.

loans.use: to buy timber to make more furniture.

loans.name: Clement And Tresfold Group

texts.en:
Tresfold, 37, and Clement, 29, have been business partners for two years. They own a Zoona mobile money transfer business in one of Lusaka's busiest bus stations. They are both married and live in Lusaka with their wives. Tresfold and Clement used to work for a bus service together. They each diligently saved money from their salaries, and eventually were able to open a Zoona shop at the bus terminal. Currently, their business is their only source of income and they make all the transactions themselves. Tresfold and Clement say they enjoy running their own business because it gives them freedom to make their own decisions. They describe their business as the easiest way for people in Zambia to transfer money safely.

Tresfold and Clement have requested a Kiva loan to increase their working capital to serve more customers sending and receiving money at their shop and grow their business.  This is the first time they are requesting a Kiva loan. As young micro-entrepreneurs in Zambia, working capital is very difficult to find. Tresfold and Clement appreciate the opportunity to be linked to Kiva lenders. 

Tresfold and Clement have large aspirations for their business.  One day, they plan to become the largest Zoona mobile money transfer agents in the capital city of Lusaka. They believe their loan is the next step in helping them achieve this goal.

loans.use: To increase their working capital to serve more customers sending and receiving money at their shop and grow their business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is a primary bananas and sugar cane growing region. She has 8 children and has been doing this work for 15 years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, crops, personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Source of income!' Her biggest challenge is 'Lack of market , poor roads.' Animals on the farm have been given no names.

Mary was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Low interest rate.' This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Meets customers financial needs.'

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit her family', Mary replied 'Improve living standard.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Mary owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, solar power' but does not have 'electricity, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Omaro

texts.fr:
Âgé de 31 ans, marié et père d’un enfant, Mr Omaro vit avec ses parents  dans la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Mr Omaro n’a pas eu la chance de faire des études, raison pour laquelle il s’est vite basé sur les activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat vente des téléphones portables et pièces de rechange, depuis plus de 5 ans. Il est très bien sollicité par ses clients pour la qualité de ses articles. 
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle, Mr Omaro a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y’a  3 ans, il est à son quatrième  prêt  individuel  dont les 3 précédents ont été bien remboursés.  
Avec ce financement  il compte acheter 15 téléphones portables et une importante quantité de pièces de rechange à Bamako, il effectue sa vente dans son kiosque au marché à une clientèle mixte en espèce. Avec ce financement, il envisage avoir sur un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qu’il utilisera pour subvenir à ses besoins et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Dans les jours à venir, il envisage d’agrandir son activité pour attirer plus de clients.
texts.en:
Omaro is 31 years old, married and father to one child. He lives with his parents in the town of Koutiala (in the Sikasso region). 

Omaro did not have the opportunity to study and for this reason he started to build up income generating activities at an early age, in particular the purchase and sale of cellphones and recharge units; he has been doing this for more than five years now. He is in great demand from his customers as a result of the quality of his products. 

In order to satisfy customer demand, Omaro turned to the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, three years ago and he is now on his fourth individual loan, the three previous loans having been repaid in full.

With this loan he is planning to buy 15 cellphones and a significant quantity of recharge units in Bamako. He sells his products for cash in a kiosk in the market to a diverse customer base. With this loan he is expecting to make a monthly profit of 90,000FCFA which he will use to provide for his needs and to invest in his business. In the future he plans to expand his activity to attract more customers.

loans.use: to buy cellphones and recharge units.

loans.name: Theodocia

texts.en:
Theodocia a 30-year-old married woman who lives in Caldwell, Liberia. She has two children, ages 1 and 5, who both attend school and live at home.
Theodocia runs a table where she sells cosmetics in her community market. She makes a good profit in her business since there are many young people who go to work and attend school in her area.
Theodocia is requesting a loan to buy different kinds of cosmetics to attract her customers.
She hopes to have an international business contract by exporting her products and also hopes to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy different kinds of cosmetics to attract her customers.

loans.name: Diatigui

texts.fr:
Âgé de 34 ans, marié à 2 femmes et père de 4 enfants. Mr Diatigui  mène des activités de commerce notamment la vente des vêtements prêt à porter depuis plus de 5 ans. Cette activité lui procure assez de revenus, sa demande est souvent très grande, car il reçoit beaucoup de clients par jour. Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle et l’agrandissement de son activité, Mr Diatigui a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, il est à son  1er prêt  individuel. Ce prêt sera  utilisé pour augmenter son stock en achetant une importante quantité de prêt-à-porter de différentes sortes. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako et souvent au Burkina Faso, effectue sa vente dans sa boutique au grand marché à une clientèle mixte en espèce. 
Avec l’agrandissement de son activité, Mr Diatigui envisage réaliser un  bénéfice mensuel de 40.000 FCFA  qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement de son prêt, satisfaire aux besoins de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Diatigui is 34 years old, married to two women and father to four children. He is a trader and has notably been selling ready-to-wear clothing for more than five years. This activity generates sufficient income and there is strong demand for his clothing as he has a lot of customers every day. In order to satisfy customer demand and expand his business, Diatigui has turned to the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso and is on his first individual loan, 

This loan will be used to increase his stock by buying a significant quantity of ready-to-wear clothing of various sorts. He gets his supplies in Bamako and quite often in Burkina Faso. He sells his clothing for cash in his shop at the Grand Market  to a diverse customer base. With the expansion of his business, Diatigui is expecting to make a monthly profit of 40,000FCFA which he will use to repay his loan, provide for his family's needs and to invest in his business.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear clothes.

loans.name: Tahani

texts.en:
Tahani is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her son appears in the photo. Tahani is a 35-year-old married woman from Jabalia city. She is a mother of six children; four sons and two daughters. For the past ten years, Tahani and her husband have been working in a small shop selling soft drinks for kids; it is a good business and located in a crowded area. Tahani and her husband would like to improve their shop.

Tahani took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a machine for making ice cream. This will improve the shop and increase its productivity.

loans.use: to buy a machine for making ice cream in her shop.

loans.name: Sana

texts.en:
Sana is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her son appears in the photo. Sana is a married woman from Jabalia city. She lives with her husband and three children; one son and two daughters in a simple house. Sana's husband works as an employee in the public sector and this is the only source of income to the family. Sana and her husband would like to improve the home conditions and buy all the necessary things. 

Sana took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a solar system for heating water using sun. This will provide the family hot water for the daily use.

loans.use: to buy a solar system for heating water using the sun.

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
Denis is 30 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has two children. For the past seven years, Denis has been working hard to manage his boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Denis has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials for making clothes to sell, and will help Denis to generate greater profits and take care of his family members. Denis hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his shop more. 

Denis is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Denis who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more materials for making clothes to sell

loans.name: Gayane

texts.en:
Gayane lives in Gyumri town with her son. She has already been involved in the retail business for five years. She sells clothing and dressmaking supplies from her house and gathers income for her family. Her son helps his mother and they are working hard to gather a good income and sustain their living. Gayane purchases the stock from a neighboring country and sells it to locals. Now she is asking for financial support to be able to purchase a new stock of clothing.

She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Therefore, this loan is very important for Gayane to be able to continue her business and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for a new stock of clothing

loans.name: Ketevan

texts.en: Ketevan is a 26-year-old married woman. She lives in a small village in the Lanchkhuti district with her husband, sister-in-law and son. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have a plot of agricultural land where maize and nut trees are grown. They sell the harvested products to local retailers. As the income is only seasonal, Ketevan decided to start an additional business. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 1000 GEL. With the received credit she will purchase a cow and will start a dairy business. This will significantly improve the income of her family.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more sheep for her husband's farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and run one Fresh Life Toilet

loans.name: Deogratias

texts.en:
Deogratias is 56 years old. He is married with two children aged 18 and 32. He will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during maize production: farmers need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, like seeds, from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers to increase his maize production

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney is 34 years old, married with three children aged between seven and fourteen. He will use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer for maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer for maize production

loans.name: Tsira

texts.en: Tsira is a 47-year-old married woman. She lives in a small village of Khobi district with her husband and two sons. The family runs an agricultural business. They have two cows and they produce dairy products. In addition, they have land where maize is grown. Each member of the family works hard to ensure a good harvest, which is sold to local retailers. As the income is only seasonal, Tsira decided to start her own stable business. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of 1,000 Gel for a trading business. She will begin to trade with clothes and will increase the income of her family.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Hawraa

texts.en: Hawraa is a 23-year-old single woman. She is from Lebanon and has owned a clothes shop since 2009. She has six years of experience working in selling clothes.  Today, she is applying for a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase a new winter clothes collection and be able to increase her profits by large percentages. She is very positive about her future and wishes to expand her operation by opening a shoe shop next to her existing store.

loans.use: to purchase a new winter clothes collection

loans.name: Zeina

texts.en:
Zeina is a 23-year-old married woman from Lebanon living with her husband and only child. In 2009, she opened her own shop where she sells flowers in addition to cosmetics and toys. Her husband has worked as a gardener for the past 12 years and they combine forces to gather enough money to be able to pay everyday expenditures. 

Today, she is asking to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to increase her store’s inventory of toys, beauty products and flowers. Zeina intends to vary her products to attract more customers and earn higher income. In the future, she hopes to expand her business into other areas.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory of toys, beauty products, and flowers

loans.name: Ramzieh

texts.en: Ramzieh is a 51-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and six children. Her husband has worked as a baker for the past 30 years. As for her, she has arranged a special room at her house where she has been selling clothes, makeup, and cosmetics since 2011. With her loan requested from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l, she will purchase cosmetics and a wide variety of clothes for the wintry weather. In the future, Ramzieh looks forward to opening a proper shop where she will better display her products and therefore catch the attention of a wider clientele.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics and a wide variety of clothes

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara is a 53-year-old widow. After her husband's death and with no children to support her, she had a hard time supporting herself. Fortunately, she had an old sewing machine to work on. Day by day she gained an excellent reputation in the neighborhood, thanks to the quality of her work and affordable prices. The old sewing machine that she had before was very slow and she had to work long hours, sometimes late at night to earn enough income to support herself.

When she heard about Izdiharona's qard hassan product for widow women she took a loan to change her old sewing machine and buy fabric to reduce her work hours and increase her profit. She is aiming to grow her business and increase her profits.

The story of Sara and her sewing business is just one of the many examples of Izdiharona's work for economic development clients.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and fabric.

loans.name: Felecien

texts.en:
Felecien is 62 years old. He is married and has seven children. He will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer in order to increase his maize production. With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers during maize production.

loans.name: Wahe

texts.en:
Wahe is a 51-year-old married Lebanese man who lives with his wife, who works as tailor, and their three children. Wahe owns a place where cars can park safely. He also works as security at his town’s municipality to earn more income and help his family to live in good conditions. 

Today, Wahe is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase a motorcycle to arrive at work easily without facing traffic. Regardless of his old age, Wahe works very hard to earn enough income to support his family well and be able to pay for life's many expenses.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Garmiah

texts.en:
Please meet 43-year-old Garmiah from Liberia. She lives in the community surrounding Airport. She is married to a driver; she did not attend school; and has three children between the ages of 9 and 25, two of whom are in school and live at home. 

For the past four years Garmiah has been selling frozen food such as fish, chicken, and pigs' feet. She started this business with a little amount from her husband. She learned this business from her aunty. Garmiah likes her business because of the way people respond to it. She is requesting a loan to purchase more frozen food such as fish, chicken, and pigs' feet for her business. She hopes to have more money to sustain her family.

loans.use: to purchase more frozen food such as fish, chicken, and pigs' feet for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase water pumps and pipes.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 33-year-old married Lebanese man living with his wife and their three children who attend school. Ali has owned a restaurant since 2010, where he serves delicious bean dishes. His wife has worked as an English teacher at a local school since 2008 to help her husband with the expenses. 

Today, Ali is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to pay for his children's educational fees. His main objective is to provide his children with a good education until graduation. In the future, Ali wants to expand his work to earn a higher income to better support his family.

loans.use: to pay for his children's educational fees

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en:
Kassem is a 38-year-old married Lebanese man who lives with his wife and two children. He is the main income earner of the family. Kassem has worked at repairing fridges and washers since 1994.  Over the years, Kassem has been able to build a good number of clients because of his friendly personality and competent repairing services. His wife is currently unemployed. 

Today, Kassem is asking for a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase a car for his work to reach his clients more quickly and he is also willing to expand his operations geographically to increase his revenue and improve his family’s living standards.

loans.use: to purchase a car in order to reach his clients more quickly

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 52 years old. She is married and has five children. She will use her Kiva loan to buy fertilizer in order to increase her maize production. With the profits from her farming, Christine wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during maize production

loans.name: Manasseh

texts.en:

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during maize production

loans.name: Zeina

texts.en:
Zeina is a 52-year-old Lebanese widow who lives with her five children, some of whom are still attending school. After her husband’s death, Zeina became the only one responsible for her family. This is why she she has worked diligently at producing food for the past 13 years. Her products are sold to her community and people really enjoy her tasty and delicious provisions. 

Today, Zeina is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase a used car for her business. She says that the car will definitely ease her operations, especially when purchasing foodstuffs to continue her production. She is also planning to start visiting grocery stores, supermarkets, etc. to sell them her food to make a good income and improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase a used car to make it easier to purchase and deliver food for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase dairy goats.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a repeat borrower, aged 49 years old. She is a widow with four children. 

Ruth applied for a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to pay her children’s school fees. She faces the challenge of little business turnover from her commercial farming, so she decided to come to UGAFODE for a loan to pay and take her children back to school. She is paying the tuition in order to lay a good foundation for her children to be successful in future. 

In the photo is Ruth with a Ugafode staff member (the gentleman).

loans.use: To pay tuition

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of maize and yams, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy lives in the Nkubu area of Kenya. She has three children and has been doing this work for 15 years. Her primary income sources are milk, tea, and crops.

Nancy stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is "profits earned" and that her biggest challenge is "insufficient water." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Mwendwa & Mike."

Nancy was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "'Better and quick services." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi Kilimo's required micro-finance training session, and she stated, "Co-guarantee mechanism."

Nancy's highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how the loan will benefit her family, Nancy replied, "Help pay school fees."

As part of Juhudi Kilimo's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Nancy owns a cow and a pig, but does not own poultry, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, running water, a sewing machine, a TV, and a DVD player, but does not have electricity or solar power.

loans.use: to construct a zero grazing unit.

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.en:
Euphrasie is 37 years old. She is married and has six children. She will use her Kiva loan to buy fertilizer in order to increase her maize production. With the profits from her farming, Euphrasie wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during maize production.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is 41 years old, married, and lives in Margibi County with her five children, who are between the ages of 15 to 30. Three of her children attend school. Margibi County is the largest rubber producing area in Liberia. Martha's husband is a teacher. 

For the past three years, Martha has been selling charcoal. She learned how to sell from her uncle's wife. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. She enjoys how supportive she is to her family. Her plan is to build her house.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is 23 years old. She is married and has two children, ages five and three. She will use her Kiva loan to buy fertilizer in order to increase her maize production. With the profits from her farming, Chantal wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. loans.name: Cassien

texts.en:
Cassien is 46 years old. He is married and has five children. His wife works as a farmer. 

He will use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. loans.use: To buy more fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of maize and cassava, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Polmar

texts.en:
Polmar is 24 years old and lives in Unidos, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. He is still single. Polmar has a motorcycle business and earns approximately PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. 

Polmar has requested a loan to buy some motor parts. He has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Polmar hopes to be successful in his business.

loans.use: to buy some motor parts.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of maize, gari (fermented cassava flakes) and pepper.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy concrete blocks, sand, rods, windows, a door, cement, etc.

loans.name: Dirga

texts.en:
Dirga is a Balinese artisan who specializes in hand-carved sculptures. He would like to invest in a bulk purchase of wood in order to prepare a large stock of sculptures for sale during the holiday season.

Dirga has been selling through NOVICA since 2004. This is his story:

"Most of my family members are carvers, for it is a family legacy that has endured several generations. You could say I was born with a talent to carve, which I developed by merely observing my parents and relatives at work every day. My inspiration comes from Balinese customs and traditions. Competition is hard here in Bali, for there are many expert carvers, making the life of a carver a very uncertain one. It means that I must excel, so hopefully my sculptures will be welcomed. 

"I work on my own, so the amount of products I can carve is limited and so are my sales. This microcredit will make it easier for me to buy larger amounts of wood and increase my stock. Every piece I carve with my own hands is done with love and happy thoughts. That is why I would like to thank you so much for your support."

loans.use: to invest in a bulk purchase of wood for his sculptures.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 50 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Margibi county, which is the largest producing rubber plantation in Liberia. All her children are in school and are between 15 and 25 years old. 

For three years now she has been involved with a business at the market. She was taught how to sell by her aunty. She started this business by selling fufu (dough made of cassava) in the market. Now she makes more profit and has more customers. 

She is asking for a loan to buy more fresh fish for her business. Her plan is to expand her business even more.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish for her business.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 39 years old, and she is residing in Buchanan, the capital city of Grand Bassa County. The county is located by the sea and is known for their beaches and fish. In addition, many logging companies are also located in the city. 

She is single and has seven children aged between 1 and 17 years old; only six of her children are in currently school, and they are living at home. For the past two years she been selling cosmetics. A problem she faces is the rainy season. She started this business by selling for her mother. She sells for six days in a week, spending nine hours each day on her business. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase cosmetics for her business. Her plan is to build her house. She would like to thank the supporters of BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 34 years old. He is a father of three children. His wife works as a farmer. 

He will use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers during maize production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of maize so as to prepare more of her tasty ‘kenkey’

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels and sell greater quantities of provisions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels and sell greater quantities of cooked rice

loans.name: Chiaka

texts.fr:
Mr Chiaka est né en 1963 à Koutiala, marié à 3 femmes et père de 6 enfants. Il réside à Koutiala dans une grande famille. 
De profession, tôlier-soudeur, Chiaka exerce en plus de cette activité les activités  vente de pièces détachées de gros porteurs (pneus et jante d’occasion, lame- ressort, etc.) Mr Chiaka dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle exigeante, a fait recours à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est en son  premier prêt. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako et Koutiala et effectue sa vente  dans son garage à Koutiala. 
Mr Chiaka espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 80.000 FCFA par mois avec ce prêt, qui lui permettra de subvenir à ses besoins, rembourser les intérêts du prêt, et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Chiaka was born in 1963 in Koutiala. He has three wives and six children. He lives in Koutiala in an extended family. A sheet metal worker and welder by trade, Chiaka also sells spare parts for trucks (used tires and wheel rims, springs etc). With the goal of meeting the needs of his demanding clientele, he has turned to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and is now on his first loan. He stocks up in Bamako and Koutiala and sells out of his auto shop in Koutiala.

Mr. Chiaka hopes to earn an average monthly income of 80,000 West African francs, which will allow him to provide for his needs, pay off the interest on his loan, and reinvest the rest in his business.

loans.use: to buy spare auto parts.

loans.name: Soline

texts.en:
Soline is 61 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have spent 30 years farming. He will use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming, Soline wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf.  All borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers for use during maize production.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 50 years old and she is very responsible with her household obligations since she has always been known to provide the best for her family. She currently lives with her husband and three children at Lower Salug Daku, Mahayag Zamboanga del, Philippines. She is a farmer who plants corn and beans.

Jocelyn wants to increase sales. Consequently, she has requested a loan that will enable her to purchase seeds, compost, and fertilizer, among other items, so that she can continue to put bread on the table in her home.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, compost, and fertilizer for farming.

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina is 38 years old, married, and lives at Brgy. Polao, Tangub City, Philippines. With a desire to earn, she decided to raise pigs on her own.

Through Paglaum MPC Divina obtained the capital to purchase her piglets and feed. Now, she is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP to buy additional feed. She really hopes and prays that her business will grow and benefit her family, in addition to the income of her husband. Someday, she wants to build a concrete pig cage to easily keep more sanitary conditions.

loans.use: to buy additional feed for her piggery

location.town: Tangub-P-7 Polao Tangub City  Misamis Occidental

loans.name: Anacurita

texts.en:
Anacurita is widowed and has six children. She is 72 years old and lives in Puntod, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Anacurita is a farmer and grows a variety of vegetables to earn a living. She has been doing this for 30 years. 

Anacurita has requested a loan to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers and pesticides. She has been a member of PMPC for 13 years. In the future, Anacurita hopes to have enough savings for her family's future.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is from  Balamban, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She  is 49 years old and is married with four kids. 

In 2010, Rebecca applied for her membership with PMPC. Hearing all the benefits, she never hesitated to become one. She maintains the status of being a member in good standing and repays her obligations in a timely manner.

Rebecca is asking for financial assistance of 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy farm inputs and fertilizers. Through this loan, she hopes to increase her income and be of help in the expansion of her business. She has found assistance for her financial needs through Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative, and she is very thankful with all her heart.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs and fertilizers.

loans.name: Bonaventure

texts.en:
Bonavanture is 29 years old. He is married and has two children. He has been a maize farmer for the past five years. 

He will use Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during the maize production.

loans.name: Luz Elena

texts.es: Luz, a sus 54 años de edad, vive con su esposo y su hijo. Se dedica a trabajar en su propio negocio, una tienda de abarrotes donde ofrece todo tipo de productos de la canasta familiar. Inicialmente el negocio lo abrió su esposo con el ánimo de generar los recursos económicos necesarios para su familia, pero desde hace 4 años ella se encarga totalmente del establecimiento debido a que el señor comenzó a trabajar en construcción. Durante este tiempo la tienda ha crecido y se ha dado a conocer en el sector, donde sus clientes cada vez se satisfacen más por el servicio prestado, ya que es organizado y está bien surtido, lo que genera una buena imagen para su establecimiento. La cliente utilizará el crédito para comprar más surtido (productos lácteos, cárnicos, productos de aseo, aceites, granos, pastas, galletería, mecato, entre otros), de esta manera podrá tener mayor disponibilidad y variedad de productos que le solicitan sus clientes y a veces no posee, así evitará perder ventas y, por el contrario tendrá la oportunidad de incrementar sus ingresos para continuar aportando a la economía del hogar. Luz manifiesta que su principal desafío son el alza de los precios de algunos productos y la competencia, sin embargo esto no la detiene para seguir luchando y avanzar hacia el cumplimiento de sus objetivos, pues sueña con ampliar su tienda para que le genere más rentabilidad y así poder terminar de pagar las cuotas de su vivienda propia, en la que podrán disfrutar de una mejor calidad de vida y bienestar.
texts.en:
Luz is 54 years old and lives with her husband and her son. She works at her own business, a grocery store where she offers all kinds of products for the family food basket. Initially, her husband started the business with the aim of generating the necessary income for their family, but 4 years ago Luz took over the business completely as her husband started working in construction. During this time the shop has grown and has become known in the area, where her clients are more and more satisfied with the service offered, since it is organized and well stocked - which projects a good image of her business.

Luz will use the loan to buy more stock (dairy products, meat products, cleaning products, oils, grains, pasta, cookies, pastries etc.), and thus she will be able to have a larger amount and variety of products. Sometimes customers ask her for products that she has run out of, and so this will help her to avoid losing sales and also give her the opportunity to increase her income to continue supporting the family finances. 

Luz says that her biggest challenge is the increase in prices of some products and her competition. However, this will not stop her from continuing to fight and make progress towards completing her objectives, as her wish is to expand her business to generate more profit. This will mean that she is able to finish paying the fees on her own home, and so enjoy a better quality of life and well-being.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her grocery store.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna is an experienced agronomist from the village Achajour in the Tavush region. Her family consists of her husband, her school-age son and daughter, and her elderly father-in-law. 

Susanna, with the help of her family members, is engaged in breeding cows, sheep, hens and turkeys. She is also cultivating wheat, grass and several fruits (plum, fig, blood orange, grapes, apple, pear and walnut). Farming is the only source of income for the family. Susanna's husband helps her sell the agricultural products in the local market. 

As the family's needs are increasing day by day, they need to find more sources of income to cover their basic needs. For this reason, Susanna needs a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a heifer and some forage for the livestock. As this is her first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history. Susanna and her family will be very thankful to the lenders for their good will in helping them collect the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase a heifer and some forage for the livestock.

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen is a private entrepreneur from Gyumri city in the Shirak region. He lives with his wife and two little children (8 and 5 years old). 

Karen runs a retail shop of shoes and clothes. His store was very small and was located in the territory of a bigger market previously. It's already four months since he has changed the location of the store to a central one; he has also expanded the store. 

He currently needs to develop his business further to be able to more effectively meet the increasing needs of his family. A loan of USD 3,000 will be a great support to this ambitious entrepreneur and will enable him to buy a new assortment of goods (shoes and clothes) to resell in his store. 

Karen and his family will be very grateful to all the lenders for helping them to collect the needed amount of loan to improve and develop their business.

loans.use: to buy a new assortment of shoes and clothes to resell in his store.

loans.name: Seneida María

texts.es: Seneida, a sus 52 años de edad, es casada y madre de 5 hijos. Se dedica a trabajar en su negocio, una papelería que inició hace varios años, aprovechando la ventaja de estar ubicada cerca a un colegio, donde los niños carecían de un establecimiento cercano que ofreciera estos productos.  Trabaja todos los días y ha notado que su negocio ha ido creciendo poco a poco. El crédito que solicita desea invertirlo en la compra de una fotocopiadora e impresora, realizar unas adecuaciones locativas y comprar surtido al por mayor (lápices, cuadernos, colores, entre otros) de esta forma podrá aumentar los servicios que presta y tendrá más variedad de artículos disponibles para satisfacer los requerimientos de su clientela. Esto se reflejará positivamente en el incremento de sus ingresos, con lo que espera cumplir el sueño de  ampliar su negocio, tenerlo más surtido y aumentar así su clientela. Seneida es consciente que para lograrlo debe seguir trabajando con empeño y dedicación para poder tener una estabilidad económica favorable y disfrutar con su familia de un mejor bienestar.
texts.en:
Seneida, 52, is married and the mother of five children.  She makes a living working in her business, a school supplies store she started several years ago to take advantage of being located near a school where the children needed a nearby store that sold these products.  She works every day and has noticed that her business keeps on growing little by little.

Seneida wants to use the loan she's requesting to buy a photocopier and printer, to make some modifications to her space, and to buy supplies wholesale (pencils, notebooks, colored pencils, and others).  This way she'll be able to expand the services she provides and have a greater variety of items to sell and satisfy her customers' needs.  This will be reflected in an increase in her sales.

Seneida hopes to achieve her dreams of expanding her business and having it better supplied to increase her clientele.  She knows that to do this she has to keep on working with determination and dedication to have good economic stability and enjoy greater well-being with her family.

loans.use: to buy a photocopier and printer, to modify her space, and to buy supplies

loans.name: Esmaragdo

texts.es: Esmaragdo, con 53 años de edad, vive con su esposa y dos hijos. Lleva más de 30 años dedicado a la ebanistería, trabajando en su propio taller, elabora diferentes artículos en madera según los requerimientos de sus clientes, por problemas de salud se vio obligado a cerrar su taller, debido a esto su familia entró en una crisis económica. Sin embargo, luego de luchar contra su enfermedad, hace 3 meses abrió nuevamente su taller en el cual trabaja todos los días en horas de la tarde, pues alterna su labor trabajando como empleado en otros negocios similares para complementar los ingresos con los cuales solventa las necesidades básicas de su hogar. El cliente es un hombre que se esfuerza por salir adelante, trabajador y pujante, siempre va en busca de alternativas que le ayuden a progresar, por esto se motiva a solicitar el apoyo del crédito con el que comprará activos fijos (sierra sinfín, máquina pulidora y rotadora) y realizará adecuaciones locativas; esto le permitirá prestar un mejor servicio y podrá realizar la entrega de los productos de manera oportuna con un excelente acabado, cuidando el reconocimiento que posee por la calidad de sus productos. Esmaragdo desea seguir trabajando arduamente para que en un futuro cercano pueda dedicarse tiempo completo a su taller y espera que éste le genere los recursos económicos suficientes para dar a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Esmaragdo, 53, lives with his wife and two children.  He’s been a cabinetmaker for more than 30 years working in his own shop.  He manufactures various items out of wood according to his customers’ wishes.  Health problems forced him to close his shop and his family was plunged into an economic crisis as a result.  However, once vanquishing his illness, he reopened his shop three months ago and works there every evening for he earns extra income also working as an employee in other similar firms in order to cover his basic household needs.

He is a man that strives to get ahead; he’s hardworking and determined and is always seeking alternatives that will lead to progress which is what motivates him to request support from a loan to buy fixed assets (band saw, sanding machine and lathe).  He will also make physical improvements to his shop to provide better service and be able to deliver excellently finished items in a timely fashion thus maintaining the good reputation he’s earned because of the quality of his products.

Esmaragdo wants to continue to work hard so that in the near future he will be able to work full-time in his shop that he hopes it will generate sufficient income to give his family better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy machinery and to make some physical improvements to his shop.

loans.name: Esperance

texts.en:
Esperance is 60 years old. She will use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizers in order to increase production. With profits from her farming, Esperance wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf. All borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing, as well as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers during maize production.

loans.name: Seryozha

texts.en:
Seryozha is from Agarak city in the Syuniq region. He lives with his mother and his wife. Seryozha and his mother work in the factory. To be able to meet their needs, the family is also engaged in keeping a cow and in cultivation of several fruits (peach, cherry, plum, quince, pomegranate, fig, blood orange, pear and walnuts). The fruits of this particular region are famous all over the country and have high demand in the market. 

Seryozha currently wants to increase the number of cattle to be able to cover the increasing needs of his family. A loan of USD 3,000 will be a huge support to this hard-working man and his family and will help them purchase three cows. Seryoja and his family highly rely on the good will of the lenders and will be grateful for helping them to sustain and develop their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase three cows.

loans.name: Gregory

texts.en:
Gregory came to the United States from the Dominican Republic ready to build a new life for himself. He found a fresh start distributing hair care products for a large company. Over time, he found that the many hair salons he was selling to were looking for fresh new products. Gregory saw his chance to finally be in business for himself and earn enough to be financially independent. 

Gregory’s business imports hair products and sells them to beauty salons. The business has been growing substantially and Gregory has used his savings to purchase a new warehouse space. With this loan, Gregory will be able to fill the warehouse with enough hair products, allowing him to reach more clients. The loan will also help Gregory build his credit, allowing him to receive a larger loan in the future.

Help Gregory grow his business and build a better life for himself.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise in order to meet the growing demand for his products.

loans.name: Sandra Milena

texts.es: Sandra es una mujer de 35 años de edad que durante 11 años ha trabajado como empleada en diferentes restaurantes ubicados en el centro de la ciudad, pero, desde hace 3 años el jefe del último restaurante en el que trabajó le dio la oportunidad de librar el negocio para que ella se quedara con él y así fue como se convirtió en propietaria de su actual negocio. Cuenta con el apoyo de 3 empleados directos y trabajan todos los días desde las 8:00 am hasta las 9:00 pm; de esta manera ha logrado generar los ingresos suficientes para solventar las necesidades básicas de su hogar. La cliente es una mujer trabajadora, pujante y activa que lucha constantemente para sacar adelante su negocio, por esta razón solicita el crédito para comprar insumos (verduras, granos, arroz, gaseosas, mecato, frutas y licor) así tendrá los materiales disponibles para preparar los alimentos y satisfacer los gustos de sus comensales, pues de ellos dependen los buenos resultados que obtiene en su labor. Sandra pretende seguir trabajando arduamente para que en un futuro pueda cumplir el sueño de montar otra sucursal de su restaurante, ubicado también en el sector donde ya es reconocida y, de esta manera poder mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Sandra is 35 years old. For a period of 11 years she was employed at various restaurants throughout the city center, but 3 years ago, she became the owner of a restaurant, when her boss at the time left the business and granted her the opportunity to take over the place. This is how Sandra became a business owner.

She has the support of 3 employees, and together work every day from 8:00 am to 9:00 pm. This is how Sandra has been able to generate the income to meet the basic needs of her home. Sandra is very hardworking, dedicated and active, and she works relentlessly to ensure that her business thrives. For this reason, she is requesting this loan to buy supplies (such as vegetables, dry grains, rice, soft drinks, snacks, fruits and liquors), to have various ingredients needed to prepare the dishes to suit her customers' requests, as it is from them that the positive outcome of her business depends on. 

Sandra plans to continue to work very hard, so that one day she may accomplish her dream to open another restaurant, situated in the same area where she is now well-known, and in this way, continue to improve her livelihood and that of her family.

loans.use: to buy supplies like vegetables, dry grains, rice, soft drinks, snacks, fruits and liquors

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis is looking forward to having the financial freedom to enjoy his family and start his own charity projects one day. His first step was to move from Colombia to Miami. After arriving, he found a job working for a manufacturer of consumables for cutting and welding. While earning money for his family, he developed strong relationships with businesses in need of other industrial products. This need sparked a new idea and, almost six years ago, Luis started his own business, Bumar International.

Luis has reached a pivotal point. The businesses he supplies products to are beginning to grow and expand. Luis has the opportunity to grow with them; but he needs the inventory in order to do so. With this loan, Luis will be able to purchase the goods to fulfill his customer’s demand. 

Help Luis grow his business and be able to spend more time with his family and help others in his community.

Check out Luis’s business: http://www.bumarinternational.com/

loans.use: To purchase the industrial products requested by a new contract

loans.name: Frances

texts.en:
Imagine raising two sons by yourself and still having the energy to implement your vision. You could be picturing Frances. A native of Boston, Frances has worked in the IT industry for many years while putting her two teenage sons through school. All the while, she has had a vision for software products aimed at understanding cultural differences, history, education and commerce around the world. She has spent years investigating the market and is finally ready to launch her business and her first product.

Before she launches, however, she needs to hire lawyers to patent her product. She’s been able to fund herself entirely up until this point. With this loan, Frances will able to protect her intellectual property and launch her first product.  

Help a single mother launch her vision and fund an education for her two sons.

loans.use: to pay legal fees to patent her software product

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Two and a half years ago, Juan and his wife Ingrid came to the United States with the hope of leading more financially independent lives. One year ago, Juan started his own business, J&I Mobile Express. 

Juan had worked in a similar business doing technical assistance and also had been working in the same field in the Dominican Republic, his natal country. He sells mobile phones and accessories, offers repairs, and also offers remittance services to Latin America. His store is located within a large laundromat and he opens 7 days a week from 10:00 am to 7:00 pm. 

"I started my own business because I wanted personal growth... the business is actually my passion. I like to offer great customer service and meet customer expectations," he says. Juan needs a loan in order to pay for a new computer and buy more inventory to meet the growing demand. He hopes to someday expand his store into its own location.

Help Juan achieve his entrepreneurial dreams!

loans.use: To pay for a computer and more inventory.

loans.name: Donaldo De Jesus

texts.es: Donaldo de 34 años habita al norte de la ciudad y con su cónyuge y su hijo de 4 años. Desde hace 5 años su madre le propuso iniciar el negocio de preparación y venta de comidas corrientes. La idea fue puesta en marcha y resultó exitosa, porque muy pronto llegaron al negocio sus clientes y con ellos muchos referidos. Hoy vende almuerzos en la mañana y todo lo que es fritura por las tardes; su negocio está ubicado en su domicilio donde vende de contado y a crédito durante todos los días,  desde las 5 de la mañana hasta las 7 de la noche. Sus compras las realiza en depósitos de víveres en el centro de la ciudad, de contado, para obtener buenos precios y trasladarlos a su clientela a quien quiere tener satisfecha para lograr su retorno. Donaldo tiene como meta independizar el negocio de su vivienda  y más adelante comprar su casa. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer finánciamelo que hace ala Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará víveres, como arroz, aceite, harinas; con ello se propone aumentar su capacidad productiva y con ello las ventas y las utilidades.
texts.en:
Donaldo, age 34, lives to the north of the city with his wife and their four year old child.  Five years ago his mother suggested to him starting the business of preparing and selling daily meal specials.  The idea was put into motion, and the result was successful.  This is because his customers came to his business very quickly, and with his customers he got a lot of referrals.

He now sells lunches in the mornings and all kinds of snacks in the afternoons.  His business is located at his home, and he sells for cash and credit every day from five in the morning until seven in the evening.

He makes his purchases at supply warehouses in the center of the city.  He buys for cash in order to get good prices and pass those on to his clientele.  He wants them to be satisfied in order for them to return.

Donald’s goal is to have the business independent of his home.  Later, he wants to buy his house.  He is currently applying for a Kiva loan, his first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to buy supplies like rice, cooking oil, and flour.  He will do this in order to increase his production capacity.  With this he will increase sales and profits.

loans.use: to buy supplies like rice, cooking oil, and flour.

loans.name: Oscar Jesus

texts.es: Oscar de 46 años de edad, habita en el municipio de Malambo, área metropolitana de la ciudad, con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 14 y 18 años. Desde hace 10 años, Oscar se ha dedicado a la actividad comercial, desde su propio negocio, vendiendo ropa, y electrodomésticos, pero antes, desde muy joven trabajaba en ello para otros. Sus ventas de hoy las realiza de contado, con una frecuencia diaria, todos los días de la semana y desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. Sus compras las realiza  en un municipio fronterizo, donde consigue precios especiales y directamente a sus proveedores. Los principales clientes de Oscar son sus propios vecinos y familiares; su meta es incrementar las ventas y mejorar la calidad de vida en su familia y aunque su mayor desafío consiste en alcanzar fuentes de financiación, hoy ha logrado un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa, jeans, y electrodomésticos, porque pretende aumentar los inventarios para vender mucho mas y ganar un poco mas.
texts.en:
Oscar is 46 years old and lives in the municipality of Malambo, which is a metropolitan section of the city.  He lives with his wife and his two children, ages 14 and 18.  For the past 10 years, Oscar has managed his own retail business in which he sells clothes and household appliances.  He previously worked for other people since he was a young man.  

Oscar currently conducts cash sales on a daily basis.  He works every day of the week from 8:00 A.M. to 8:00 P.M.  Oscar makes his sales at a border town where he is able to obtain special prices directly from his suppliers.  His main customers are neighbors and relatives.  Oscar’s goal is to increase his sales and improve his family’s quality of life.  However, his greatest challenge has been obtaining funding sources.  Today he is applying for a Kiva loan, his first form of financing through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  He will use the money to buy clothing, jeans, and household appliances because he intends to increase his inventory.  This will enable him to sell more and earn a little more profit.

loans.use: to buy clothing, jeans, and household appliances to sell.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is dedicated to her family. A natural entrepreneur, she started a business in order to provide a livelihood for herself and her mother. Her business, Sisi's Mobile Grooming, offers a unique service where the dog groomer comes to you. Cecilia’s mother, an experienced dog groomer, works one-on-one with customers while Cecilia, who is pursuing her degree in business management, runs the business side. 

“We have been blessed to draw thousands of customers and be busy all day long,” explains Cecilia.

With popularity comes an obstacle. There is more demand than one mobile grooming truck can service in a day. With this loan, Cecilia will be able to purchase additional blow dryers, clippers, and dog grooming tables and tubs in order to service her growing customer base. 

Help Cecilia expand her business and support her mother’s passion as a livelihood. 

Check out Sisi's Mobile Grooming online: http://www.sisimobilegrooming.com/

loans.use: To purchase additional dog grooming equipment

loans.name: Riccardo

texts.en:
Do you know what an Arepa is? When Riccardo moved to his neighborhood in Queens, NY, he was dismayed to find that no one in the area was familiar with this Venezuelan specialty. After 10 years of working as a truffle salesman, he decided to bring his dish to light in the community by opening up his own restaurant. Arepas Café started out as just a tiny restaurant, but was instantly popular in the community. One year after opening, Riccardo saw an opportunity to expand the size of the restaurant and increase his staff to 14. Riccardo employs many members of the community, including his teenage daughter.  

Arepas Café has become quite popular in Queens. It has received 4 stars on Yelp and brings in locals from all different walks of life. After accomplishing one dream, Riccardo has set his sights even higher. He has purchased a second location and needs a loan in order to stock up the restaurant and spread the word about his new location. 

Help Riccardo open up a new restaurant and bring the unique flavor of his dish to a new community.

loans.use: To stock up his new restaurant and spread the word to potential customers

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is from Balamban, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 44 years old and is married with 2 children.

In 2010, Mary Jane applied for membership with Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative (PMPC).  On hearing of all the benefits, she did not hesitate to become a member. She maintains her member status in good standing and makes her loan repayments in a timely manner.

Mary Jane is asking for financial assistance of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy additional tools for farming and farm supplies. Through this loan she hopes to increase her income and facilitate the expansion of her business.  She has found assistance for her financial needs through Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative and she is very thankful with all her heart.

loans.use: to buy additional tools for farming and farm supplies.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 27 years old, married, and has one child.

Marites is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 6,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Marites has been raising pigs for two years now and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Marites would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Alda

texts.en: Alda is requesting a loan for $600 to improve her business. She runs a kiosk that helps her support her family, and will use the loan to buy petrol and diesel to sell. She opened her kiosk a year ago using her own working capital of $300.  She is a hard-working woman and hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy petrol and diesel.

loans.name: Charisma

texts.en: Charisma is married and works hard to support her family by running a food-vending business in the Philippines. She is requesting a loan for PHP 5,000 from NWTF to buy additional ingredients like rice, sugar and milk. She has been in this line of work for two years and would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional food items to sell such as rice, sugar and milk.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 26 years old, with four children, two of whom are in school.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Josephine is borrowing PHP 8,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Josephine has been raising pigs for two years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Leilanie

texts.en:
Leilanie works hard to support her family. Leilanie is married and has a buy-and-sell gasoline business in the Philippines.

Leilanie requested a PHP 6,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional gallons of gasoline to sell.

Leilanie has been in this business for five years now. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional gallons of gasoline to sell.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 33 years old and lives in Dao, Pagadian City. She is married, with four children.

Mary Jane has a retail business where she sells a variety of things. She has had this business for one year. She requested a loan to have capital for her retail business, like basic commodities.

Mary Jane has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) for one year. In the future, she hopes to have her own grocery store.

loans.use: to expand her retail business by buying additional inventories.

location.town: PAgadian - Dao, Pagadian City Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en: Lucila is 59 years old, married and the mother of five children. She works very hard to provide for her family by running a general store in the Philippines, and is requesting a loan for PHP 5,000 from NWTF to buy additional items to sell such as canned goods, milk, sugar and cream. Lucila has been in this business for 23 years, and would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional household goods to sell.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a tailoring business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 18,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy clothing and other dressmaking materials for her tailoring business.

Alma has been in this business for eight years. She earns additional income from pig-fattening.

Alma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy clothing and other dressmaking materials for her business.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en: Riza is 40 years old, married and the mother of two children.
